    Aer Lingus repeats call to reject Ryanair offer

    Updated: 14:27, Wednesday, 18 July 2012
    Tweet
    • Article
    • Audio (1)

    Aer Lingus has issued a statement this morning calling on shareholders to reject Ryanair's offer.

    Aer Lingus has issued a statement this morning calling on shareholders to reject Ryanair's offer.

    The company will be writing to shareholders in the next 14 days to set out in detail its reasons for rejecting the offer.

    It believes reasons for European commission prohibition is now even stronger as it says the number of routes that Ryanair would monopolise has sharply increased.

    It says that the share price of €1.30 Ryanair is offering "fundamentally undervalues Aer Lingus and represents a significant discount to the intrinsic value of the business."

    It also says that the price is a discount of 30% to Aer Lingus' gross cash per share of €1.87 totalling €1,002m.

    The statement also adds that the "gross cash on the company's balance sheet more than pays for Ryanair's offer."

    Yesterday, Ryanair submitted a formal take-over for Aer Lingus with a 694 million euro offer.

    Ryanair owns 29.8% of Aer Lingus, acquired between 2006 and 2007, and recently made an all cash bid for the airline.

    Ryanair is seeking acceptance of the bid by 13 September.

    An investigation is also being carried out into Ryanair's current holding by the UK Competition Commission.

    • Keywords:
    • aer lingus,
    • ryanair
